post_text: #FlashbackFriday: Earlier this year, the PTO at Roslyn Elementary School funded six LEGO WeDo 2.0 kits to host a LEGO Robotics Club for students. Unfortunately, just three weeks later, schools closed, but 4th grade members were still eager to participate remotely and share in their love of building. Using LEGOs and/or other household materials, club sponsor Ms. Kristine Barnes, a second grade teacher, challenged the students to create imaginative playgrounds, and the Roslyn school community was able to vote for their favorite designs. Congratulations to winners Frankie J. Petronis (1st), Ethan McAllister (2nd) and Jayson Phillips (3rd). #ASDTogether

post_text: #ASHS2020: Members of the Abington Senior High School Select Choir hosted their Annual Spring Coffee House virtually. Choral Director Lori Wolf hosted the Zoom, with performances by students Sierra Charles, Emma Convery, Isabella DiPasquale, Joanna Ford, Timothy Hack, Rory Miller, Gabrielle Oliveira, and Rachel Reale. Seventy-one attendees composed of parents, relatives, friends, teachers, and administrators joined the student performers for presentations of moving music selections. The 13 graduating choir members were also celebrated during the online event. Despite the pandemic and power outages due to recent storms, the student performers persevered to share their artful performances by any means necessary—cars, generators, alternate locations, and even candlelight. #ArtsinASD #asdtogether

All of the faculty was asked to show their support of Juwan’s fight by wearing their Custom Ink shirt or yellow for pediatric cancer. post_text: It was a productive professional development day in Abington School District on Friday, with a focus on cultural responsiveness and technology integration. Guest speakers included Ms. Susan Tranchina—a Google Certified Trainer and teacher in West Long Branch, NJ, who held a session entitled “Transforming Instruction with Digital Tools”—and Dr. Crystal Lucky from Villanova University, and Dr. Ronald Whitaker of Cabrini University, both of whom have worked with District staff during professional development days over the past year to facilitate critical conversations related to equity, inclusion, and diversity. Dr. Lucky engaged our secondary professional staff in scenario-based discussions, while Dr. Whitaker worked with elementary professional staff to align Cultural Responsiveness with Universal Design for Learning through use of concrete examples of classroom instructional strategies for engagement of diverse learners. #asdproud

post_text: Did you know that the plastic in your old markers needs to be recycled just like a water bottle? The NHS & NJHS at Abington Junior High School is proud to partner with Highland Elementary School in conjunction with the Crayola ColorCycle campaign to repurpose used markers rather than sending them to landfills. All around Highland, students and teachers will collect used markers that are ready to be discarded, including those that students might have around their homes. All brands, including highlighters and dry-erase markers, will be accepted in the drop-off boxes around the school. Additionally, the AJHS students conducted research and created a PSA to educate the Highland community about the importance of recycling these items. #ASDProud #ASDServiceLearning

All around Highland, students and teachers will collect used markers that are ready to be discarded, including those that students might have around their homes. All brands, including highlighters and dry-erase markers, will be accepted in the drop-off boxes around the school. Additionally, the AJHS students conducted research and created a PSA to educate the Highland community about the importance of recycling these items. #ASDProud #ASDServiceLearning
